HD34078.Type: Runaway O-type star illuminating a bow-shock reflection nebula (IC 405 region)
HD34078.Size: The star is point-like; its surrounding bow-shock arc is a few light-years across and spans only a small fraction of the Moon in typical images.
FunFacts: Also known as AE Aurigae, it was likely ejected from the Orion region after a gravitational interaction.
Its high space velocity creates a visible bow shock as it rams into interstellar material.
HD34078.Composition: Hot massive star plowing through interstellar gas; UV light and stellar wind create a bow shock and excite nearby dust/gas.

IC59.Type: Emission & reflection nebula (Ionized hydrogen region + dust reflection)
IC59.Size: Roughly a few light-years across; on the sky it's small—well under the apparent width of the full Moon.
FunFacts: Often photographed together with IC 63 as a faint, wispy complex near Gamma Cassiopeiae.
Its glow is a mix of red hydrogen emission and blue dust reflection.
IC59.Composition: Gas and dust illuminated and ionized by the nearby bright star Gamma Cassiopeiae.

IC63.Type: Emission & reflection nebula (Ionized hydrogen region + dust reflection)
IC63.Size: A few light-years across; appears as a compact patch—far smaller than the full Moon.
FunFacts: Nicknamed the 'Ghost of Cassiopeia' (often for the IC 59/63 complex).
Dense dust lanes give it a spooky, sculpted look in long exposures.
IC63.Composition: Interstellar gas and dust shaped and lit by Gamma Cassiopeiae's intense radiation.

IC405.Size: ~30–40 light-years across; spans about 1° on the sky—around 2× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: The bright star AE Aurigae is a runaway star that now lights the nebula.
Dark dust lanes cut through the glowing gas, creating the 'flames'.
IC405.Composition: Hydrogen gas glowing in emission plus dust reflecting starlight; energized by AE Aurigae (HD 34078).

IC443.Type: Supernova remnant interacting with molecular clouds
IC443.Size: ~70 light-years across; about 45 arcminutes on the sky—roughly the size of the full Moon.
FunFacts: Its complex filaments come from the shock running into dense interstellar clouds.
Associated with high-energy gamma-ray emission from particle acceleration in the shock.
IC443.Composition: Expanding supernova shock wave compressing and heating surrounding gas; strong in Hα/OIII and radio/X-ray.

IC410.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with embedded open cluster (NGC1893)
IC410.Size: ~100 light-years across; about 40 arcminutes—close to the full Moon's apparent size.
FunFacts: The 'Tadpoles' are star-forming globules being eroded by radiation from hot young stars.
It's a great narrowband target (Hα/OIII) due to strong emission and contrast.
IC410.Composition: Ionized hydrogen surrounding young cluster NGC1893; includes the famous 'Tadpoles' (dense dusty globules).

IC417.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) associated with star-forming regions in Auriga
IC417.Size: Tens of light-years across; around 40–50 arcminutes—about the full Moon's size.
FunFacts: Often imaged as part of the Auriga nebula mosaic with IC 405 and IC 410 nearby.
Contains regions of ongoing star formation embedded in dusty clouds.
IC417.Composition: Ionized hydrogen mixed with dust; powered by young massive stars in the Auriga star-forming complex.

IC434.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) / background glow behind a dark nebula (Barnard 33)
IC434.Size: The emission curtain is tens of light-years long; the Horsehead area spans ~1°—about 2× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Home to the Horsehead Nebula (Barnard 33), a famous dark nebula silhouette.
Also includes NGC2023 nearby, a bright reflection nebula in the same field.
IC434.Composition: Ionized hydrogen gas lit by σ Orionis; silhouetted dust clouds create the Horsehead and surrounding dark lanes.

IC1318.Type: Emission nebula complex (Ionized hydrogen region) around Gamma Cygni (Sadr region)
IC1318.Size: ~100 light-years across; spans several degrees—many times larger than the full Moon.
FunFacts: Often called the 'Sadr Region' and packed with intricate dark lanes in narrowband imaging.
Part of a much larger Cygnus star-forming complex rich in Hα emission.
IC1318.Composition: Large hydrogen emission region with dark dust lanes; energized by massive stars in Cygnus.

IC1340.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) / faint nebular complex in Cygnus
IC1340.Size: Tens to ~100 light-years; appears as a diffuse region that can span over a degree—several Moons across.
FunFacts: A challenging widefield target—its low surface brightness rewards long integration.
Sits in a sky region crowded with nebulae and dust lanes.
IC1340.Composition: Ionized hydrogen and dust in the rich Cygnus Milky Way background.

IC1396.Type: Massive emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with embedded cluster; includes dark globules
IC1396.Size: ~100 light-years across; ~3° on the sky—about 6× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Contains the Elephant's Trunk Nebula, a star-forming pillar of gas and dust.
So large it's best framed with widefield optics; narrowband makes its structure pop.
IC1396.Composition: Ionized hydrogen surrounding an open cluster; numerous dark globules (including the Elephant's Trunk, IC 1396A).

IC1805.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with embedded open cluster (Melotte 15)
IC1805.Size: ~150 light-years across; ~2° wide—about 4× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Heart Nebula; paired on the sky with IC 1848 (Soul Nebula).
Its central cluster is carving cavities and pillars into the gas.
IC1805.Composition: Ionized hydrogen and dust sculpted by winds from young massive stars in Melotte 15.

IC1848.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with embedded clusters and dark clouds
IC1848.Size: ~100 light-years across; ~2°—about 4× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Soul Nebula; together with the Heart it forms a famous widefield pair.
Contains multiple bright rims and dust pillars ideal for Hα/OIII imaging.
IC1848.Composition: Ionized hydrogen plus dust and dark nebula structures; energized by young stars across the region.

IC2118.Size: ~50 light-years across; about 2.5° long—~5× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Nicknamed the Witch Head Nebula due to its distinctive silhouette.
Its blue color comes from starlight scattered by fine interstellar dust.
IC2118.Composition: Dust clouds reflecting light from nearby stars, often associated with the Orion/Eridanus region.

IC5070.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) in a larger complex
IC5070.Size: ~20–30 light-years; ~1° on the sky—about 2× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Called the Pelican Nebula; it shares the sky with NGC7000 (North America Nebula).
Dark dust between it and NGC7000 creates the 'Gulf of Mexico' gap.
IC5070.Composition: Ionized hydrogen and dust; part of the Pelican / North America nebula region.

IC5146.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with associated dark nebula (Barnard 168)
IC5146.Size: ~15 light-years across; ~12 arcminutes—about 0.4× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Cocoon Nebula; the adjacent dark lane is a star-forming cloud.
The nebula is relatively compact but the surrounding dust extends much farther.
IC5146.Composition: Ionized gas around a young cluster, connected to a long dusty molecular cloud (dark lane).

LDN1235.Type: Dark nebula / molecular cloud complex (Lynds Dark Nebula)
LDN1235.Size: ~15 light-years across; about ~3° long—roughly 6× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Often nicknamed the 'Dark Shark' because of its silhouette against the Milky Way star field.
It's essentially a 'hole in the sky'—a dense dust cloud seen in absorption.
LDN1235.Composition: Cold molecular gas and dust blocking background starlight; part of the Cepheus Flare star-forming region.

LDN1622.Type: Dark nebula with illuminated rims (reflection/emission edges)
LDN1622.Size: A few light-years across; about 1°—~2× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Often called the 'Boogeyman Nebula' for its face-like dark structure.
Its dusty edges can show both reddish emission and bluish reflection depending on processing.
LDN1622.Composition: Dense dust cloud on the edge of the Orion complex; edges are lit by nearby hot stars and the Orion region glow.

NGC1952.Size: ~11 light-years across; about 6×4 arcminutes—~0.2× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: The supernova was recorded by Chinese astronomers in 1054 as a 'guest star.'
At its core is the Crab Pulsar spinning ~30 times per second, energizing the nebula.
NGC1952.Composition: Expanding debris from the 1054 CE supernova; synchrotron emission from relativistic particles powered by the Crab Pulsar.

NGC6523.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with embedded star cluster
NGC6523.Size: ~110×50 light-years; spans ~1.5°—about 3× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Lagoon Nebula; one of the brightest nebulae in the sky.
Contains the dense 'Hourglass' region, a hotbed of newborn stars.
NGC6523.Composition: Ionized hydrogen and dust lanes with active star formation; includes bright cores and dark rifts.

NGC6205.Size: ~145 light-years across; ~20 arcminutes—~0.7× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Often called the Great Hercules Cluster and visible in binoculars under dark skies.
It was the target of the 1974 Arecibo message broadcast toward space.
NGC6205.Composition: Hundreds of thousands of old stars packed into a spherical halo cluster.

NGC6611.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) + embedded open cluster (NGC6611)
NGC6611.Size: ~70 light-years; ~35 arcminutes—slightly larger than the full Moon.
FunFacts: Home to the famous 'Pillars of Creation' imaged by Hubble.
A classic narrowband target with strong Hα and OIII structure.
NGC6611.Composition: Ionized hydrogen and dust pillars sculpted by young massive stars in NGC6611.

NGC6618.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) / star-forming region
NGC6618.Size: ~15 light-years across; ~20 arcminutes—~0.7× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Omega, Swan, or Checkmark Nebula depending on the view.
Its bright ridge is a blister of ionized gas on the edge of a molecular cloud.
NGC6618.Composition: Ionized gas and dust; active massive-star formation.

NGC6514.Type: Composite: emission nebula + reflection nebula + dark nebula lanes
NGC6514.Size: ~40 light-years across; ~28 arcminutes—about the full Moon's size.
FunFacts: The dark lanes give it the classic 'trifid' (three-lobed) appearance.
A great example of multiple nebula types in one object.
NGC6514.Composition: Red Hα emission, blue reflection regions, and dark dust lanes dividing the nebula.

NGC6853.Size: ~2.5 light-years across; ~8 arcminutes—~0.25× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Dumbbell Nebula; one of the brightest planetary nebulae.
Its central white dwarf is the exposed core of the original star.
NGC6853.Composition: Expanding shells of ionized gas expelled by a dying Sun-like star; strong OIII emission.

NGC224.Size: ~220,000 light-years across; ~3° wide—about 6× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: The nearest major spiral galaxy to the Milky Way and visible to the naked eye under dark skies.
On a collision course with the Milky Way in several billion years.
NGC224.Composition: Hundreds of billions of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter; includes satellite galaxies M32 and M110 nearby.

NGC598.Size: ~60,000 light-years across; ~1°—about 2× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: One of the most distant objects visible to the naked eye under excellent skies.
NGC604 in M33 is one of the largest star-forming regions in the Local Group.
NGC598.Composition: Star-rich spiral disk with prominent Ionized hydrogen regions (like NGC604).

NGC1976.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) / star-forming complex
NGC1976.Size: ~24 light-years across; ~1°—about 2× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: The closest massive star-forming region to Earth, making it a benchmark for astrophysics.
The Trapezium cluster at its core is visible in small telescopes.
NGC1976.Composition: Ionized hydrogen and dust; powered by the Trapezium stars; part of the larger Orion Molecular Cloud Complex.

M44.Size: ~15 light-years across; ~1.5°—about 3× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Visible to the naked eye as a hazy patch under dark skies.
One of the nearest and richest open clusters.
M44.Composition: A loose grouping of young-to-middle-aged stars (the Beehive Cluster).

M45.Size: ~40 light-years across; ~2°—about 4× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: The blue nebulosity is dust the cluster is currently passing through—not leftover birth material.
A classic naked-eye object and frequent calibration target in astrophotography.
M45.Composition: Hot young stars with surrounding interstellar dust reflecting blue starlight.

M51.Size: ~60,000 light-years across; ~11 arcminutes—~0.35× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: One of the best galaxies for seeing spiral structure in small telescopes.
The companion galaxy NGC5195 is actively interacting with M51, shaping the arms.
M51.Composition: Spiral galaxy undergoing tidal interaction, triggering star formation in its arms.

M57.Size: ~1–2 light-years; ~1.4 arcminutes—tiny (much smaller than the Moon).
FunFacts: Known as the Ring Nebula; the 'ring' is a barrel-shaped shell seen nearly end-on.
Long exposures can reveal a faint outer halo from earlier mass-loss episodes.
M57.Composition: Ionized gas shell around a central white dwarf; strong OIII emission forms the bright ring.

M74.Size: ~95,000 light-years; ~10 arcminutes—~0.3× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: A classic 'challenge' Messier galaxy due to its faint surface brightness.
Its nearly face-on orientation makes its spiral pattern photogenic.
M74.Composition: Grand-design spiral with low surface brightness arms.

M78.Type: Reflection nebula with embedded star formation
M78.Size: ~5 light-years; ~8×6 arcminutes—~0.25× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: One of the brightest reflection nebulae, often showing blue tones.
Dusty environment hosts young stellar objects and faint emission features.
M78.Composition: Dust reflecting starlight from young stars; part of the Orion molecular cloud complex.

M81.Size: ~90,000 light-years; ~26 arcminutes—~0.9× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Forms a famous galaxy pair/group with M82 nearby.
Its structure resembles a scaled version of the Milky Way's classic spiral form.
M81.Composition: Large spiral galaxy with a bright central bulge and well-defined arms.

M97.Size: ~2 light-years; ~3 arcminutes—~0.1× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Owl Nebula due to two darker 'eye' cavities.
Often observed in the same field/region as the Surfboard Galaxy (M108).
M97.Composition: Expanding ionized gas shell around a central white dwarf; OIII gives it a greenish cast in images.

M101.Size: ~170,000 light-years; ~28 arcminutes—about the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Its many star-forming regions make it rich in Hα emission (for a galaxy).
Despite large angular size, it can be tricky visually because its light is spread out.
M101.Composition: Large spiral disk with numerous bright Ionized hydrogen regions and star-forming knots.

NGC4258.Size: ~135,000 light-years; ~19 arcminutes—~0.6× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Hosts a bright active nucleus powered by a central black hole.
Has 'anomalous arms'—features not matching the optical spiral pattern.
NGC4258.Composition: Spiral galaxy with an active supermassive black hole and unusual 'anomalous arms' seen in radio/X-ray.

NGC281.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with embedded open cluster; dark globules
NGC281.Size: ~35 light-years; ~35 arcminutes—slightly larger than the full Moon.
FunFacts: Nicknamed the Pacman Nebula due to its shape.
Contains dense Bok globules where new stars are forming.
NGC281.Composition: Ionized hydrogen with dust lanes and Bok globules; powered by young cluster IC 1590.

NGC772.Size: ~200,000 light-years; ~7 arcminutes—~0.2× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Its single prominent arm is a sign of tidal interaction with nearby companions.
A good example of how galaxy interactions distort spiral structure.
NGC772.Composition: Large spiral with asymmetric arms likely influenced by a smaller companion (NGC770).

NGC1499.Size: ~100 light-years long; ~2.5°—about 5× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the California Nebula because it resembles the outline of California.
It's a classic Hα target—often surprisingly faint in broadband.
NGC1499.Composition: Ionized hydrogen region energized by nearby hot stars; broad, diffuse Hα glow.

NGC1579.Type: Reflection nebula with emission components; star-forming region
NGC1579.Size: A few light-years; ~10 arcminutes—~0.3× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Often called the Northern Trifid or a 'lost' nebula due to its subtle mixed emission/reflection nature.
Contains young stars still embedded in dusty cloud material.
NGC1579.Composition: Dust reflecting light from young stars plus faint hydrogen emission; embedded in molecular cloud.

NGC1893.Type: Open cluster embedded in emission nebula (part of IC 410)
NGC1893.Size: ~20 light-years; ~12 arcminutes—~0.4× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: The cluster's massive stars are responsible for carving and lighting the surrounding nebula.
Great target for pairing star color with narrowband nebula data.
NGC1893.Composition: Young open cluster of hot stars ionizing surrounding gas in IC 410.

NGC1977.Type: Reflection/emission nebula (part of the Orion complex; 'Running Man')
NGC1977.Size: ~5 light-years; ~20 arcminutes—~0.7× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Often called the Running Man Nebula, just north of the Orion Nebula (M42).
Its bluish reflection contrasts nicely with the red emission of M42 nearby.
NGC1977.Composition: Dust reflecting blue starlight plus faint emission from nearby ionized gas; near M42.

NGC2024.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with dark dust lanes
FunFacts: Known as the Flame Nebula, adjacent to the bright star Alnitak.
Dense dust hides much of the star formation occurring within.
NGC2024.Composition: Ionized hydrogen with heavy obscuring dust; embedded in Orion molecular clouds.

NGC2070.Type: Giant Ionized hydrogen region / starburst nebula (core of Tarantula Nebula)
NGC2070.Size: ~200+ light-years region; on the sky ~15 arcminutes—~0.5× the full Moon.
FunFacts: One of the most active star-forming regions in the Local Group.
If it were as close as the Orion Nebula, it would cast shadows on Earth.
NGC2070.Composition: Extremely active star-forming region containing the massive cluster R136; ionized gas, dust, and stellar winds.

NGC2244.Type: Open cluster embedded in emission nebula (Rosette Nebula, NGC2237/2238/2246)
NGC2244.Size: Cluster spans ~35 light-years; the Rosette nebula complex spans ~100+ light-years and ~1.3°—~3× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: The central cavity is carved by intense winds and radiation from the cluster's hot stars.
The larger Rosette complex contains enough material to form thousands of Sun-like stars.
NGC2244.Composition: Young cluster whose radiation and winds hollow out a cavity in the surrounding Ionized hydrogen region.

NGC2264.Type: Composite: open cluster + emission nebula + reflection nebula + dark nebula (Christmas Tree / Cone region)
FunFacts: The cluster's star pattern resembles a Christmas tree; the Cone Nebula sits nearby.
Home to very young stars and protostars still embedded in their birth clouds.
NGC2264.Composition: Young open cluster with surrounding gas/dust; includes the Cone Nebula and Fox Fur nebulosity.

NGC2359.Type: Emission nebula (Wolf–Rayet bubble / Ionized hydrogen region)
NGC2359.Size: ~30 light-years across; ~10 arcminutes—~0.3× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Nicknamed Thor's Helmet due to its winged bubble shape.
A textbook example of how massive stars sculpt surrounding gas with fast winds.
NGC2359.Composition: Bubble of ionized gas blown by strong stellar winds from the Wolf–Rayet star WR 7.

NGC6888.Size: ~25×18 light-years; ~18×12 arcminutes—~0.6× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Crescent Nebula; its bright arcs trace shock fronts in the shell.
Shows strong OIII and Hα—great for bicolor narrowband.
NGC6888.Composition: Shell of ionized gas blown by the Wolf–Rayet star WR 136 interacting with earlier stellar ejecta.

NGC6946.Size: ~40,000–60,000 light-years; ~11 arcminutes—~0.35× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Nicknamed the Fireworks Galaxy because many supernovae have been observed there.
Sits near the plane of the Milky Way, so foreground dust can dim it.
NGC6946.Composition: Dusty spiral rich in gas; high star formation rate.

NGC6960.Type: Supernova remnant filament (part of the Veil Nebula)
NGC6960.Size: The full Veil spans ~3° (~6× the Moon); this western segment spans ~1° (~2× the Moon).
FunFacts: Known as the Western Veil / Witch's Broom near star 52 Cygni.
OIII filters dramatically increase contrast by highlighting the shock-heated gas.
NGC6960.Composition: Filamentary shock fronts from an ancient supernova; strong OIII emission outlines the filaments.

NGC6992.Type: Supernova remnant filament (part of the Veil Nebula)
NGC6992.Size: The eastern Veil filaments span ~1° (~2× the Moon); the full Veil complex spans ~3° (~6× the Moon).
FunFacts: Often called the Eastern Veil; its delicate, lace-like filaments are iconic in narrowband.
Part of a single supernova explosion that occurred roughly 10,000 years ago.
NGC6992.Composition: Thin sheets of shock-heated gas seen edge-on; bright in OIII and Hα.

NGC7000.Size: ~100 light-years across; ~2°—about 4× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the North America Nebula due to its continent-like outline.
The dark lane between it and the Pelican is the 'Gulf of Mexico'—dense obscuring dust.
NGC7000.Composition: Ionized hydrogen and dust; shares complex with IC 5070 (Pelican Nebula).

NGC7023.Size: ~6 light-years; ~18 arcminutes—~0.6× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Iris Nebula; famous for blue petals around a bright core.
A strong example of a photo-dissociation region where UV light alters molecular gas.
NGC7023.Composition: Dust reflecting starlight from HD 200775; surrounding molecular cloud glows in infrared.

NGC7293.Size: ~2.5–3 light-years across; ~16 arcminutes—~0.5× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Known as the Helix Nebula; one of the closest planetary nebulae.
Contains thousands of comet-like knots—dense clumps being photo-evaporated.
NGC7293.Composition: Expanding shells of ionized gas from a dying Sun-like star; complex knotty structure in the halo.

NGC7380.Type: Open cluster embedded in emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region)
NGC7380.Size: ~100 light-years region; ~25 arcminutes—~0.8× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Often called the Wizard Nebula for its shape in narrowband images.
Rich Hα emission and dark dust make it a rewarding long-integration target.
NGC7380.Composition: Young open cluster whose hot stars ionize surrounding gas; includes dark clouds and bright rims.

NGC7479.Size: ~90,000 light-years; ~4 arcminutes—~0.13× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: A dramatic bar structure makes it a favorite target for galaxy imagers.
Shows dust lanes along the bar where gas is compressed.
NGC7479.Composition: Stellar bar funnels gas inward, fueling star formation and possibly nuclear activity.

NGC7635.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) / bubble nebula with embedded cluster
NGC7635.Size: The main bubble is ~10 light-years across; the surrounding nebulosity spans ~1° (~2× the Moon).
FunFacts: Known as the Bubble Nebula; the 'bubble' is a wind-blown cavity seen nearly in profile.
Often photographed with NGC7635's neighbor cluster M52 in the same wide field.
NGC7635.Composition: Ionized gas bubble blown by the massive star BD+60°2522 into surrounding molecular cloud.

FunFacts: Known as the Tulip Nebula; often imaged with the nearby Cygnus X-1 region in widefields.
Narrowband imaging reveals strong Hα structure and contrasting dust.
SH2-101.Composition: Ionized hydrogen with dark dust lanes; energized by massive stars in the Cygnus region.

SH2-129.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with faint OIII features (incl. 'Flying Bat' field)
SH2-129.Size: Several degrees across—many times the full Moon; widefield target.
FunFacts: Often photographed with the faint 'Squid Nebula' (Ou4) nearby in the same field.
Large and faint—benefits from long integration and narrowband filters.
SH2-129.Composition: Ionized hydrogen with embedded dust; some regions show OIII shells and faint structures in deep exposures.

SH2-157.Type: Emission nebula (Ionized hydrogen region) with dark dust and embedded star formation
FunFacts: Known as the Lobster Claw Nebula; rich in Hα with intricate dark dust structure.
Often paired with nearby Sharpless regions in Cassiopeia/Cepheus widefields.
SH2-157.Composition: Ionized hydrogen mixed with dust pillars and dark lanes; active star formation.

SH2-188.Type: Planetary nebula (bow-shock / interaction with interstellar medium)
SH2-188.Size: ~2.5 light-years across; ~10 arcminutes—~0.3× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: Nicknamed the Shrimp Nebula for its curved, asymmetric shape.
Its arc-like form comes from a strong interaction with surrounding interstellar gas.
SH2-188.Composition: Ionized gas from an evolved star forming a one-sided arc due to motion through the interstellar medium.

SH2-240.Size: ~160 light-years across; ~3°—about 6× the full Moon's diameter.
FunFacts: One of the largest apparent supernova remnants in the sky, but very low surface brightness.
The complex filaments look like tangled spaghetti in deep Hα/OIII images.
SH2-240.Composition: Extremely faint filamentary shell of shock-heated gas from an ancient supernova; includes a pulsar candidate association.

SH2-308.Type: Emission nebula (Wolf–Rayet bubble / Ionized hydrogen region)
SH2-308.Size: ~60 light-years across; covers slightly more sky than the full Moon.
FunFacts: Known as the Dolphin-Head Nebula; a huge wind-blown bubble around a massive star.
The shell was created by stellar winds sweeping up earlier slower material into a bright rim.
SH2-308.Composition: Ionized hydrogen bubble blown by fast winds from the Wolf–Rayet star EZ Canis Majoris.
